results.notes: Found growing in wood chips under a hazelnut shrub in my garden. At first I thought it was Stropharia rugosoannulata as I found those in my garden earlier this year, and tried to inoculated the wood chips near this spot with pieces of stem and cap from those. However, it did not have an annulus or any sign of a veil on the underside of the cap. And the gills were not purple/grey. They were kind of orange. The spore print was orange.

results.notes: Agaricus found in Montgomery, AL under live/water oak. Unfortunately the stem tore when getting it out the ground. The entire cap surface and most of the stem was stained bright yellow when I found it (curious if maybe rain pattering on it from the day prior could’ve caused this global, uniform staining)? Smelled strongly of marzipan. Not sure if this is in the arvenses section or minores? Would love any recommendations as to the ID for this one.

results.notes:
A NJMA foray collection; found by a participant. The specimen was preserved (2 fbs with undamaged caps).
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 1-Feb-24):
A full-length nrITS sequence of 570 base pairs (bps) was obtained from this collection by Steve Russell. The RiC score is 359.
The sequence BLASTs to numerous (25) accessions of Amanita “sp-IN34” with 99.0~99.8% similarity, including those associated with my own collection of this species, obs 257597 (from NY) and obs 419357 (from NJ). Most of the accessions of this list are by Steve Russell.
This eastern North American taxon is closely related to the European A. gioiosa and the Asian A. orientigemmata. For more information see obs 257597.

results.notes:
A NJMA foray collection found by Brandon Roddy. The specimen was preserved.
Slowly staining orange-red in the cap after exposure to air.
This was a surprise find: the park is just outside of the Pine Barrens region, but still feels very much like this ecosystem with its mixed oak-pine woods and sandy soils, and I have never seen or collected any members of Leccinellum sensu lato other than Leccinellum albellum in the core Pinelands. In other words, I don’t expect species like L. rugosiceps and L. crocipodium, which MO507349 resembles, to grow in the outer Atlantic coastal plain of NJ.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 1-Feb-24):
> A full-length nrITS sequence of 760 base pairs (bps) was obtained from this voucher by Steve Russell. The RiC score is only 12 and Steve notes that the sequence is of low quality.
> A BLASTn-100 search of this sequence shows it to be 98.6~99.1% similar to 3 top accessions that happen to have come from iNaturalist observations:
- PP156193, 99.1% similarity & 100% query cover: https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/190089757 (from North Carolina)
- OP549158, 98.6% similarity & 100% query cover: https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/129940796 (from Indiana)
- OP549160, 98.6% similarity & 100% query cover: https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/129940185 (from Indiana)
> This collection is also conspecific by ITS with another post of mine from NJ, obs 426898. The sequence of the latter is rather messy due to shifting heterogeneity, but the first 400+ bps are in excellent agreement with the present sequence.
> This species appears to be the best candidate for Peck’s Boletus rugosiceps, which was later transferred by Singer into Leccinum, as per the original description and subsequent interpretation of it by later authors, such as Smith & Thiers (1971), Snell & Dick (1970) and, lately Bessette et al. (2000 & 2016). The ITS sequence of the present entity is quite unique, as presently there is nothing closer than 90% in GenBank, and the query covers for those accessions are low due to the very dissimilar nature of the respective sequences. Although Leccinum has recently been drastically recircumscribed by Kuo & Ortiz-Santana (2020) to include many entities and even genera that are not part of the core Leccinum, viz. sect. Leccinum and sect. Scabra, genus Leccinellum was shown to be hopelessly polyphyletic.1 This species obviously has the gestalt of Leccinellum sensu lato, not Leccinum sensu stricto, but, at least for the time being, Leccinum rugosiceps is the current name.
Reference:
1 https://www.fs.usda.gov/research/treesearch/60533

results.notes: This Hygrocybe appears every time there is a lot of rain. This was once an airplane runway used to transport blue berries and cranberries. It has not been used for years and a layer of sand has accumulated on top of the hard clay surface. Small pine tree and other vegetation are establishing themselves. The cap is scarlet red with wine red coloring in the middle. It is quite delicate and usually falls apart after being carted around for several hours. By the time we get it home it is mushy and blackening. Cap- 3cm Stipe- yellow with some red tint, a bit flattened. Gills – yellowish turning black with time, 3 tiers of lamellae. Not conical and does not turn black immediately.

results.notes:
Full work up with reagent application/microscopy performed(all images/steps included in order of performance).

Fruiting beneath non-native Paper birch(Betula papyrifera) and a few non-native maples(Acer).
Cap: light grayish brown. KOH reddish on cap(see home test images below).
Pore surface: creamy white staining light brown where handled. Pores are large, round(2-4 per mm). Pore surface depressed/sunken toward stem.
Stem: scabers are light brown. Darker brown toward base(NOT BLACK). Stem tapered at apex(top).
Mature specimen stem apex streaked reddish.
Context slightly pink after 20min.
Extreme base slightly blue naturally.
Iron Sulfate applied to flesh=light blue reaction from FeS04(see images).
Microscopy::

Crush Mount of Hymenial tissue in KOH:
Hymenial cystidia: mostly clavate also lageniform (see images). Non ejected spores in crush mount are yellow in KOH.
Cap Tissue Crush Mount in KOH:
Red in KOH.
Pileipellis: collapsing terminal elements(curved/swollen) see images.
Stem Tissue Crush Mount in KOH:
Caulocystidia are bundled.
Most all lageniform(see images).
Spore Printed a portion of cap directly on an additional glass slide for ejected spore microscopy. Mounted in KOH.
Spore print: Brown(see images).
Mounted in KOH: spores Fusiform, many with slightly curved tips, smooth and medium sized.
Yellow in KOH.
Sliced/dehydrated specimen and bagged for herbarium collection/genetic record.

results.notes:
Growth Habit: I saw about 10 individuals scattered among fallen leaves, localized to a few trees where the edge of the forest meets a road. There was an Acer platanoides that seemed to be central to the scattered group of mushrooms, though they did not form a distinct ring around this tree. There were also a few small Fagus grandifolia (DBH<5"), and a fallen log.
Cap: Convex in shape with an incurved margin, surface is smooth, the cap feels firm, the color is purplish-brown, you can feel an umbo but the top looks basically flat from the side.
Gills: The gills are lavendar with medium spacing (~2-3 per mm) and are descending at an interesting angle (see photos).
Stem: Connected centrally to cap, very slight taper to the base, surface is white but rubs away to reveal purple. Several of the stems appear to have been chomped on, and a red-backed salamander was seen at the base of one of the mushrooms when I moved some leaves aside. (I wonder if the salamander was eating it.) The stem is firm, but the tissue on the inside is spongier, almost like it has a pith. The whole mushroom is pretty firm. I was able to make a longitudinal cut through the entire mushroom by ripping with my fingers at the stem and up through the cap.
Base: Clavate in shape, white mycelium present in dirt. At the base just above the dirt is where the most vibrant purple could be seen. On the specimen I took, there was a root embedded in the base of the mushroom, like the fungi was growing around it. There also appeared to be rhizomorphs coming from the base, unless they were actually plant roots.
Veil: I did not see any veil remnants on the cap, there was no ring present on the stem, there was something at the base that may have been a volva but it was unclear as there is a lot of debris present.
Spore Print: Light in color, white or maybe yellow. (I need to take another one with better contrast.)
Smell: The smell reminds me of modeling clay.

results.notes:
Three mature basidiomata en plein forme found growing in a tight cluster in the middle of a wide but short dead-end dirt road in the typical pine-oak barrens habitat. They fruited shortly after the big rains from the remnants of hurricane Ian and were slightly waterlogged. The soil was still very wet.
The overall morphology can be inferred from the photos. The cap color is very accurate as the photos were taken under light-neutral conditions (scattered natural light).
The largest cap (single fb) measured 5.7 cm in diameter. The lovely color of the cap disc was closest to 7A5 (pastel red) in the Methuen Handbook of Colour by Kornerup & Wanschler and oac693 in the Online Auction Color Chart (turned much darker red upon drying). However, one can see a much darker red pigmentation spot/area where the two caps are conjoined (see photos). It’s not clear if this is an aberration or whether the dominant paler color of the pileipellis is the result of natural fading due to the weather and/or environmental conditions (the location is exposed to the afternoon sun from the south). The cuticle peeled slightly less than 1/2 R (two trials).
The gill plates en masse had a pale creamy hue to my eyes, so I expected the color of the spore print to be the same (non-white); however, the spore print taken on aluminum foil was stark white. Very few short gills and gill forks were present.
The flesh didn’t stain when injured on the upper stipe, and the observed deepening of the color in the wound can probably be attributed to a change in the refractive properties of the injured tissue more than anything else. However, one can clearly see “discoloration” at the base of the stipe where effort was made to remove excessive soil/dirt, but even this can perhaps be explained by the reaction of the waterlogged flesh to manipulation.
The taste, though non-bitter and non-acrid, was chalky and greasy and thus unpleasant. The odor was either nondescript or mild/fungal.
Fatto/Kibby codes applicable to the morphological properties of this species are either AIKNPT (if cap color is considered some shade of red or salmon) and CIKNPT (if cap color is interpreted as some shade of ochraceous/orange). The first code corresponds to species praeumbonata and rosea, but neither is a fit. The second code lists heterophylla (doesn’t fit) and stricta. The second species authored by Murrill is rather obscure when in comes to searching it online; there appear to be no pictures of vouchers identified as R. stricta. Murrill’s description of the cap is “isabelline with testaceous and ochraceous hues”, while Fatto/Kibby’s description is “tan with brick or ochraceous hues (dark grayish-yellow 91 with reddish brown or ochre)”. Fatto/Kibby list a few southern russulas under these codes, all authored by Murrill. I don’t think that pursuing these entities is going to be fruitful either.

results.notes: This species used to be called S. sibiricus in the west, however, molecular phylogenetic analysis shows that it is probably better lumped in with S. americanus. This species is strictly associated with 5-needle pines. I found this collection in late spring/early summer growing with Pinus flexilis in foothills P. flexilis/J. scopulorum scrublands. Prior to this find I had only seen this species at high elevations in the late summer with Pinus albicaulis.

results.notes:
Fruiting on a moss covered/downed Alnus rubra.
Really was hopeful this beautiful collection was in the Flammula(Pholiota) alnicola complex when I encountered them. They smell wonderfully cinnamon’esque(almost akin to Matsutake or pumpkin spice latte).
Bitter taste also checked out for true F. alnicola.
However, to my surprise, the spore prints for this collection are smoky purple black!
Definitely NOT Flammula(Pholiota)!
All features clearly add up to Hypholoma fasciculare(including performed microscopy-spores are yellow in KOH and F. alnicola has brown spores in KOH). Although, the deep red Areolate/flat topped cap disc and pronounced reddish streaked stem bases are features I’ve never encountered with H. fasciculare in my 15+yrs(1000s of encounters with them).
Perhaps this collection is a variety in H. fasciculare yet to be described…
Harvested entire caespitose cluster for further study/herbarium collection.
Features:
Cap: reddish orange/areolate disc, yellow/green margin. Gills greenish yellow. Purplish once home from spore drop.
Gills: purple green. Attached.
Stem: yellow/green deep reddish brown streaks from base to mid stem.
Odor: cinnamon or pumpkin spice latte.
Spore printed glass slide for microscopy.
MICROSCOPY
Spore Print: smoky purple black(see images).
Spores: ellipsoid with germ pore(F. alnicola has distinctly ovoid spores).
KOH= spores yellow in KOH
(F. alnicola has spores that are brown in KOH)!!

Fruiting bodies Brilliantly bioluminescent in 395nm light(used my escolite) see images.
Dehydrated all specimens and bagged for herbarium collection/genetic record.

results.notes:

results.notes:
Growing under an old and dying planted larch tree. The habitat is not a bog.
Tamarack is pretty rare in NJ, unless you’re in the extreme northern part of the state, so I had to consult a tree expert in the past to find out what this tree was.
This is the second observation of S. clintonianus from NJ and one of the southernmost records reported on MO (including those posts still incorrectly called S. grevillei), coinciding with the natural range of L. laricina.
results.location_name: New Jersey, USA

results.notes:
Lobster mushroom ( Hypomyces lactifluorum ) attacking a honey mushroom ( Armillaria mellea ).

Found on ground near tree, but there was a mesh ground cover that it had grown through.

The ring, shape and size, gills, and clustering is strongly reminiscent of honey. The fuzzy coating is reminiscent of the lobster attack. The group of mushrooms looked like an orange, lumpy ball from 100 feet away.

Very late in the year for honeys, but it has been warm for this region, and above 60F during the day for the last week.

Please confirm if you have seen something like this!

results.notes:
These are popping up around my withering zucchini plant in a raised bed, downtown suburban area.

I thought they were ringed honeys but the variation as they age is confounding, and I can’t seem to pin it down from all the googling.

No evident spores, no rings, they start as bells and flatten and some develop a dark brown ring around the cap as they grow.

I’m wondering if they’re easily/confidently identifiable as a species safe to eat.

Thanks!
results.location_name: Redwood City, California, USA
